channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: When Gangs Killed Gay Men for Sport: Australia Reviews 88 Deaths
item.media:description: Steve Johnson in December on a ferry to visit the site of his brother Scott’s death in 1988. Mr. Johnson pressed the authorities to revisit the case, and a new inquest has been opened.
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.description: The authorities are reviewing the deaths of 88 men between 1976 and 2000 to determine whether they should be classified as anti-gay hate crimes.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: For Leaders of U.S. Allies, Getting Close to Trump Can Sting
item.media:description: President Trump with Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain at the White House on Friday. A close relationship with American presidents is regarded as vital by allies and foes alike, but particularly by countries like Britain, Canada, Japan and Mexico.
item.description: The leaders of Britain, Mexico, Japan, Canada and even Australia have been burned after what seemed like friendly interactions, causing political troubles.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: No Uncertain Terms: Why a ‘Three-Line Whip’ Means Business
item.media:description: Houses of Parliament in London. British lawmakers will vote on Wednesday on whether to start the talks to leave the European Union.
item.description: The “three-line whip“ that Britain’s Labour Party leader declared for voting over the Brexit bill is derived from the hunt. It keeps the dogs, and the lawmakers, in line.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Brazilian Tycoon Eike Batista Is Arrested After Returning Home
item.media:description: Eike Batista in Rio de Janeiro on Monday after he gave himself up to the Federal Police.
item.description: Mr. Batista, once Brazil’s richest person, had been a fugitive since Jan. 26, when police discovered he had gone to the United States.
item.dc:creator: DOM PHILLIPS

item.title: Israel’s Hard-Liners Want to ‘Go Big’: Annex a Settlement
item.media:description: The Israeli settlement of Ma’ale Adumim, near Jerusalem in the West Bank.
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.description: Right-wing Israeli politicians emboldened by the Trump administration are eager to annex Ma’ale Adumim, but Palestinians say such a move would be the last straw.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER

item.title: Iran Warns U.S. Not to Escalate Missile Dispute
item.media:description: The Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, right, with his French counterpart, Jean-Marc Ayrault, in Tehran on Tuesday.
item.description: The Iranian foreign minister said the American accusations of a missile test should not be used “as a pretext to create new tensions.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Isn’t Building Arms Depot in the Philippines, Envoy Says
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines at a predawn news conference on Monday, during which he accused the United States of building a weapons depot in his country.
item.description: The American ambassador to the nation countered President Rodrigo Duterte’s accusation, saying there was never a plan to build any depots there.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Rohingya Refugees in Bangladesh to Be Relocated to Remote Island
item.media:description: The Kutupalong refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, this month. The United Nations has called the Rohingya, a Muslim ethnic group denied citizenship in Myanmar, the most persecuted minority in the world.
item.description: The cabinet ordered officials to move migrants to Thengar Char, which is lashed by high tides year round and submerged during the monsoon season.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: Jingdezhen Journal: Ancient Porcelain Arts Thrive Again in a Chinese River Town
item.media:description: A pottery district in Jingdezhen, where a new generation is trying to revive a traditional artisan culture in the city that once produced China’s most-coveted porcelain.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Once the source of the country’s most coveted china, Jingdezhen is attracting artists from around the world to study its hallowed porcelain traditions.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Why Democracy Prevailed in Gambia
item.media:description: President Adama Barrow of Gambia being greeted last week by a guard of honor upon his arrival in Banjul, the capital. Mr. Barrow had won Gambia’s presidential election, but the incumbent would not step down.
item.description: Democracy hasn’t always worked in Africa recently. But in Gambia, the election outcome was declared legitimate, and a unified coalition force stepped in.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: What in the World: Polish City to Give Tom Hanks the Car That Put It on the Auto Map
item.media:description: A gathering of Fiat 126p enthusiasts in Krakow, Poland. “The Maluch was the beginning of an automotive revolution in Poland,” said Jacek Krywult, the mayor of Bielsko-Biala, Poland, where the car was made.
item.description: The Maluch, built in Bielsko-Biala from the early 1970s to 2000, has developed a following that apparently includes at least one prominent fan.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Owner Sues to Keep House Where Hitler Was Born
item.media:description: In 1972, the Austrian government took over the main lease of the house where Hitler was born, right, in an effort to ensure that the property would not fall into the hands of someone seeking to glorify its link to a dark history.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.description: A law that allows the Austrian government to seize the home, which could possibly be demolished, is challenged as unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Does Europe Have Foe in Trump White House? It May, E.U. Official Says
item.media:description: Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, at a news conference on Tuesday in Tallinn, Estonia.
item.description: China, Russia, radical Islam — and now the U.S. All were on the European Council president’s list of possible threats to the future of European Union.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Billionaire Is Reported Seized From Hong Kong Hotel and Taken Into China
item.media:description: Xiao Jianhua at a park in Beijing in an undated photograph. He has been missing since Friday.
item.description: The Chinese-born tycoon Xiao Jianhua, who holds Canadian and Antiguan passports, is in police custody on the mainland, a person close to him said.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.category: Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China

item.title: Dangerous Fruit: Mystery of Deadly Outbreaks in India Is Solved
item.media:description: A man comforted his sick daughter at a hospital in Muzaffarpur, India, in 2013.
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.description: Researchers had suspected that heat stroke, infections or pesticides were behind a disease that killed about 40 percent of children affected, but it seems lychees were to blame.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Papers Offer a Peek at ISIS’ Drones, Lethal and Largely Off-the-Shelf
item.media:description: Members of American Special Operations inspected a drone in Mosul, Iraq, in January. The craft had been used by Islamic State militants to drop explosives on government forces.
item.description: Documents found in Iraq and a recent surge in attacks show how the group has adapted readily accessible technology into a potentially effective new weapon.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Syria Reclaims Damascus Water Source From Rebels
item.media:description: The al-Feijeh spring, which supplies Damascus with drinking water, in Barada Valley, on Sunday. An insurgent evacuation from the area could signal an end to the water crisis in the capital.
item.description: An insurgent evacuation from the Barada Valley area north of Damascus could signal an end to the water crisis in the capital.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Iran Launches a Missile, Testing Trump’s Vows of Strict Enforcement
item.description: The missile test could reveal whether the Trump administration will make good on its promises to strictly enforce all aspects of the Iranian nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Women Killed in Yemen Raid Were Qaeda Fighters, Pentagon Says
item.description: U.S. military officials were seeking to explain reports that a number of civilians died in the firefight, which killed a Navy SEAL.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Pakistan Places Militant Tied to Mumbai Attacks Under House Arrest
item.media:description: Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, chief of the banned Islamic charity Jamaat-ud-Dawa, on Monday as he was escorted to his home where he would be under house arrest in Lahore, Pakistan.
item.description: The arrest of Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, who lived in the open for years despite a $10 million American bounty, was said to come amid new pressure by the United States.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Global Health: In South Africa, Deadly Tuberculosis Strain Is Spread Directly
item.media:description: A hospital in Durban, South Africa, in 2010. The worst-known outbreak of XDR-TB, the deadliest strain of tuberculosis, is in the Zulu-dominated mountains behind the city, where H.I.V. is also extremely common.
item.media:credit: Joao Silva for The New York Times
item.description: A study has shown that the problem is much bigger than previously realized, and that most victims contracted the drug-resistant TB not through treatment failure, but rather directly from another victim.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Myanmar Says Gunman Killed Rights Lawyer to Undermine Stability
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of people paid their respects at the funeral of U Ko Ni, a prominent Muslim lawyer, in Yangon, Myanmar, on Monday. He was shot dead the day before.
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: U Ko Ni, who was shot at Yangon International Airport, was an adviser to Myanmar’s leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte Says Drug War Will Go On as Police Plan Purge
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines, left, with Ronald dela Rosa, the national police chief, during a news conference in Manila on Monday.
item.description: The Philippine president’s vow followed a promise by the police chief to “clean house” in response to the killing of a South Korean businessman in police custody.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Hackers Use New Tactic at Austrian Hotel: Locking the Doors
item.description: The electronic key system was infiltrated and a ransom of about $1,800 was demanded, an example of a malicious and prevalent type of modern-day piracy.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Quebec Mosque Attack Forces Canadians to Confront a Strain of Intolerance
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Quebec City on Monday expressed solidarity with the Muslim community outside a mosque where six people were killed.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The suspect, Alexandre Bissonnette, was a frequent commenter on sites speaking about immigration and Islam.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and CRAIG S. SMITH
item.category: Islamic Cultural Center of Quebec City

item.title: The Interpreter: Trump’s Immigration Order Tests Limits of Law and Executive Power
item.media:description: A demonstration against President Trump’s immigration order outside Kennedy Airport in New York on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.description: Questions about the directive abound: Is it too vague? Is it constitutional? Is it effectively a “Muslim ban”? Is the president overreaching?
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB and MAX FISHER

item.title: Iraq Memo: ‘You Have Let Us Down, Trump’: Iraqis See U.S. Relations Recast
item.media:description: Hameed Khalid Darweesh, center, a former interpreter for the United States military in Iraq, was released on Saturday from detention at Kennedy Airport in New York.
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.description: Relationships between Iraqis and Americans have long been nurtured against a backdrop of war. Now Iraqis wonder if betrayal and insult will define the dynamic.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Brunhilde Pomsel, Goebbels’s Secretary and Witness to Nazis’ Fall, Dies at 106
item.media:description: Brunhilde Pomsel in 2016 in front of posters for the documentary “A German Life,” based on her experiences. Throughout her life, she insisted that she had been ignorant of Nazi atrocities during World War II.
item.description: Ms. Pomsel was the private secretary of the propaganda minister Joseph Goebbels and was one of Adolf Hitler’s retinue in his final days in a Berlin bunker.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Gazing Into Danakil Depression’s Mirror, and Seeing Mars Stare Back
item.media:description: In pools of water in the Danakil Depression, the combination of heat, high acidity and sulfur concentrations causes bright yellow chimneys to form.
item.description: Scientists are studying this area in a remote region of Ethiopia — one of the hottest places on Earth — to understand the possibilities of life on other planets and moons.
item.dc:creator: AMY YEE

item.title: Australia Says Trump Will Honor One-Time Deal to Accept Refugees
item.description: The Australian leader said President Trump confirmed that he would carry out an Obama-era deal to resettle in the U.S. migrants held by Australia on two Pacific islands.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: Trump Tells South Korea That Alliance With U.S. Is ‘Ironclad’
item.media:description: Hwang Kyo-ahn, the acting leader of South Korea, spoke by phone with President Trump from Seoul on Monday. The call followed North Korea’s warning that it could test an intercontinental ballistic missile “anytime.”
item.description: President Trump spoke by phone with Hwang Kyo-ahn, the acting president of South Korea, and the two agreed to strengthen joint defenses against North Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Trump, a Chevy and Cuba’s Uncertainty
item.media:description: Tourists in a 1957 Chevrolet Bel Air on Havana’s seafront boulevard El Malecón in 2013.
item.description: If President Trump revives the old American policy on Cuba, it’s the Cuban people who will suffer.
item.dc:creator: LEONARDO PADURA

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Abnormal Presidency of Donald Trump
item.media:description: Protesting against the immigration ban at the Supreme Court in Washington this week.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: His immigration measures reflect a streak of gratuitous cruelty.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
